The '''[[IBM]] [[computer storage|storage]]''' product portfolio includes disk, tape, [[Network-attached storage|NAS]] and Flash storage products, storage software and integrated solutions. On June 4, 2012, IBM announced a strategic approach to storage referred to as "Smarter Storage."<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM Tackles Big Data with Smarter Storage|url=http://www.infostor.com/backup-and_recovery/cloud-storage/ibm-tackles-big-data-with-smarter-storage.html|accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref> IBM has three basic tenets for Smarter Storage: efficient by design, self-optimizing, and cloud agile.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mesabi Group Commentary: IBM Smarter Storage: What a Smart Idea|url=http://public.dhe.ibm.com/common/ssi/ecm/en/tsw03138usen/TSW03138USEN.PDF|publisher=Mesabi Group|accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref>
==Disk Systems==
===Systems for enterprise workloads===
====DS8000 Series==== The IBM System Storage DS8000 is designed for high performance, reliability, and flexibility and works in a range of open server operating environments and the [[IBM System z]] mainframe. The DS8000 includes a range of features that automate performance optimization and application quality of service, as well as provide high levels of reliability and system uptime. The DS8000 offers specialized advanced functions optimized for IBM Power Systems and IBM System z servers. The DS8000 also can use self-encrypting drives for every drive tier to help secure data at rest.<ref>{{cite web|title=DS8000 disk encryption|url=http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/dsichelp/ds8000ic/index.jsp?topic=%2Fcom.ibm.storage.ssic.help.doc%2Ff2c_ds8000encryption_3ekm6r.html|work=IBM System Storage DS8000 Information Center|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref> * DS8100<ref>{{cite web|title=DS8100 (Models 921 and 931)|url=http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/dsichelp/ds8000ic/topic/com.ibm.storage.ssic.help.doc/f2c_ds8100model921_1w2znt.html|work=IBM System Storage DS8000 Information Center|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref> ** Dual 2-core [[POWER5+]]-based controllers ** Can contain up to 384 drives ** Drives can be [[Fibre Channel]] or [[SATA]] * DS8300<ref>{{cite 4-, 8- or 16-core [[POWER7]]-based controllers ** Can contain up to 1,536 drives ** 2.5" 10K and 15K RPM Drives and SSD Solid State Disk SAS-2 drives ** 3.5" Nearline-SAS drives
====XIV==== The [[IBM XIV Storage System]] is a high-end disk storage system designed to provide consistent performance, high availability and simple usability. As virtualized storage that meshes tightly with server [[hypervisors]], XIV is designed to work well in cloud and virtualized environments. The XIV Gen3 model offers 3 TB drives, providing up to 243 TB of usable capacity per rack. SSD caching (available as an option) adds up to 6 TB of management-free high-performance data caching capability to the whole array. The system also can connect to external storage via Fibre Channel (8Gbit/s) and iSCSi (1 or 10 Gbit/s).<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM XIV Storage System Gen3 model 281x-114 Information Center|url=http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/ibmxiv/r2/index.jsp|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref>
====SONAS==== IBM Scale Out Network Attached Storage (SONAS) is the IBM enterprise storage platform based on GPFS technology. This system implements [[Network-attached storage|NAS]] based protocols over a large-scale global name space. Today the system can scale out using commodity components to 30 balanced nodes and up to 14.4 PB of storage. GPFS gives the SONAS system with built-in ILM and tight integration with Tivoli Storage Manager helps move data to disk pools.<ref>{{cite web|title=Product overview|url=http://pic.dhe.ibm.com/infocenter/sonasic/sonas1ic/topic/com.ibm.sonas.doc/sonas_r_product_overview.html|work=IBM Scale Out Network Attached Storage (SONAS) Information Center|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref>
===For entry and midrange workloads===
====Storwize V7000==== [[IBM Storwize V7000]] is a virtualizing storage system from IBM based on the software from the IBM SAN Volume Controller (SVC). It can attach to storage clients via FCP, [[FCoE]] or [[iSCSI]] (1 or 10 Gbit/s) protocols and can use Real-time Compression to reduce disk space usage by up to 80 percent.
====Storwize V7000 Unified==== The Storwize V7000 Unified combines two head units running IBM SONAS version 1.4 code with the IBM Storwize V7000. It is described as unified storage because it simultaneously implements NAS protocols (such as CIFS and NFS) and block storage.<ref>{{cite web|title=Storwize V7000 Unified overview|url=http://pic.dhe.ibm.com/infocenter/storwize/unified_ic/topic/com.ibm.storwize.v7000.unified.doc/ifs_unifiedovr_082011.html|work=IBM Storwize V7000 Unified Information Center|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref>
====Storwize V3700==== IBM Storwize V3700, announced on November 6, 2012, is an entry-level system designed to meet the block storage needs of small and midsize businesses. This new system offers capabilities previously available in more expensive systems to help businesses consolidate and share data at a lower price.<ref>{{cite web|title=New IBM Storwize V3700 Takes IBM Deeper Into SMB Storage|url=http://www.crn.com/news/storage/240049891/new-ibm-storwize-v3700-takes-ibm-deeper-into-smb-storage.htm|publisher=CRN|accessdate=7 November 2012}}</ref> Key hardware features include: *Dual controllers with up to 180 TB of capacity and 8 GB of cache in a 2U 19-inch rack-mount enclosure *Up to 120 2.5-inch disk drives or 60 3.5-inch disk drives with four expansion units *Host attachment through 1 Gb iSCSI ports (standard), with optional 1Gb iSCSI, or 10 Gbit/s iSCSI/FCoE, or 8 Gb Fibre Channel expansion cards. *8GB Cache (4GB per controller) standard; optional upgrade to 16GB *RAID levels 0, 1, 5, 6, and 10 *Redundant, hot-swappable components (i.e., power supplies and fans) *AC power (110 to 240 V)
Storwize V3700 also offers management and interoperability features from previous Storwize systems, including: *Simple management capabilities *Virtualization of internal storage and thin provisioning for improved storage utilization *FlashCopy to create instant copies of data for backup or application testing *One-way data migration to easily move data onto Storwize V3700
IBM also announced future plans to use IBM System Storage® Easy Tier® technology to optimize usage of solid-state drives.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM Storwize V3700 delivers innovative and easy-to-use storage to meet needs of small and medium organizations|url=http://www-01.ibm.com/common/ssi/cgi-bin/ssialias?subtype=ca&infotype=an&appname=iSource&supplier=897&letternum=ENUS112-181#h2-sodx|publisher=IBM|accessdate=7 November 2012}}</ref>
====DS3500 Series==== The DS3500 products are made for IBM by NetApp (after NetApp purchased Engenio from LSI in March 2011).<ref>{{cite web|title=NetApp to Purchase Engenio External Storage Systems Business of LSI Corporation|url=http://www.netapp.com/us/company/news/news-rel-20110309-364618.html|publisher=NetApp}}</ref> * DS3512/DS3524 ** 6Gbit SAS single or dual-controller with two SAS host ports on each conroller. Controller options to add (per controller) either two more 6Gbit SAS hosts ports, four 8Gbit FC ports, two 10Gbit iSCSI ports or four 1Gbit iSCSI ports. ** 2U enclosure with 12 3.5" (DS3512) or 24 2.5" (DS3524) SAS drive bays ** Can use up to 192 drives using EXP3512 or EXP3524 ** 3U enclosure with 16 SAS or SATA drive bays
====DCS3700==== The IBM System Storage DCS3700 is designed to offer performance, scalability, and storage density for high performance computing environments.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM System Storage DCS3700 delivers optimal performance, scalability, and density for high-performance computing environments|url=http://www-01.ibm.com/common/ssi/ShowDoc.wss?docURL=/common/ssi/rep_ca/1/897/ENUS111-101/index.html&lang=en&request_locale=en|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref> * Dual-active intelligent array controllers enabled with Turbo Performance * 6Gbit SAS host ports standard with optional 8Gb Fibre Channel (FC) host ports * 60 SAS drive bays, with ability to scale up to 180 drives by attaching two DCS3700 Expansion Units
====DS5000 Series==== * DS5020 - Up to 112 TB physical storage capacity. Accommodates up to 16 disk drives installed within the DS5020 enclosure. It can attach up to six EXP520 expansion enclosures.<ref>{{cite web|title=DS5020 storage subsystem|url=http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/redbooks/SG247676/wwhelp/wwhimpl/api.htm?href=3-5.htm|work=IBM Midrange System Storage Hardware Guide|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref> * DS5100 - Up to 448 TB of SATA disk physical capacity or more than 268 TB of FC disk physical capacity. Eight host channels, 4 Gbit/s FC, and 8 GB cache for data.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|title=DS5100 and DS5300 storage subsystems|url=http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/redbooks/SG247676/wwhelp/wwhimpl/api.htm?href=3-4.htm|work=IBM Midrange System Storage Hardware Guide|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref> * DS5300 - Up to 448 TB of SATA disk physical capacity or more than 268 TB of FC disk physical capacity. Eight or sixteen host channels, 4 Gbit/s FC, and 8 or 16 GB cache for data and full performance activation.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
====N Series==== The IBM N Series solutions are rebranded [[NetApp]] FAS arrays, with multiprotocol architecture that natively implements block- and file- based protocols (FCP, iSCSI, NFS, CIFS, FCoE). The system is designed to offer application integration and storage efficiency, with block level de-duplication on primary data and other features.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM Storage System N series Information Center|url=http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/nasinfo/nseries/index.jsp|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref> The N Series is offered through an OEM relationship between IBM and NetApp.<ref>{{cite web|title=NetApp and IBM N series Partnership|url=http://www.netapp.com/us/partners/become-a-partner/global-system-partners/ibm.html|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref>
According to IBM, N series systems are designed to protect diverse business environment with simple, effective and affordable storage resource management.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM System Storage N series Hardware Guide|url=http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/abstracts/sg247840.html|publisher=IBM|accessdate=6 May 2013}}</ref>
BM System Storage N7000 series<ref>{{cite web|title=N7950T technical specifications at a glance|url=http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/redbooks/SG247840/4-3.htm|work=IBM System Storage N series Hardware Guide|publisher=IBM|accessdate=6 May 2013}}</ref> * Highly expandable infrastructure designed for nondisruptive expansion to more than 5.7 PB (5,760 TB) storage capacity * Can contain up to 1,440 drives * Dual (active/active) Controller configuration * 24 processors * 192 GB Random access memory
IBM System Storage N6000 series<ref>{{cite web|title=N62x0 technical specifications at a glance|url=http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/redbooks/SG247840/3-3.htm|work=IBM System Storage N series Hardware Guide|publisher=IBM|accessdate=6 May 2013}}</ref> * Consolidates block and file data sets onto a single multiprotocol storage platform, up to 3.8 PB (3,840 TB) storage capacity * Can contain up to 960 drives * Controller configurations: Single (C), Dual (active/active) (CC), Single + IO Exp (CI), Dual (active/active) (CI-HA) * Up to 4 processors * Up to 40 GB Random access memory
IBM System Storage N3000 series<ref>{{cite web|title=N3000 technical specifications at a glance|url=http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/redbooks/SG247840/2-6.htm|work=IBM System Storage N series Hardware Guide|publisher=IBM|accessdate=6 May 2013}}</ref> * N3000 Express systems offer integrated data access, intelligent management software and data protection capabilities with up to 432 TB raw storage capacity * Can contain up to 144 drives * Controller configurations: Single (C), Dual (active/active) (CC) * Up to 4 processors * Up to 12 GB Random access memory
==Tape and virtual tape systems==
===For enterprise workloads===
====TS3500 Tape Library==== Highly scalable tape library with [[Linear Tape-Open]] (LTO) technology - including LTO-6 - or TS11x0 drives. Can scale up to 16 frames, 192 drives and over 20,000 cartridges capacity per library string or up to 2,700 drives per library complex.<ref>{{cite web|title=New IBM System Storage TS3500 Tape Library Models S24 and S54 support higher density|url=http://www-01.ibm.com/common/ssi/cgi-bin/ssialias?infotype=AN&subtype=CA&htmlfid=897/ENUS108-580&appname=USN|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref>
====Tape drives==== * TS1140 - Tape drive that uses 3592 media.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM System Storage TS1140 Tape Drive Model E07 delivers higher performance, reliability, and capacity|url=http://www-01.ibm.com/common/ssi/ShowDoc.wss?docURL=/common/ssi/rep_ca/7/897/ENUS111-087/index.html&lang=en&request_locale=en|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref> * TS1060 - LTO tape drive that uses LTO generation 6 technology.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM System Storage TS1060 Tape Drive offers an Ultrium 6 Tape Drive for the TS3500 Tape Library|url=http://www-01.ibm.com/common/ssi/ShowDoc.wss?docURL=/common/ssi/rep_ca/2/897/ENUS112-162/index.html&lang=en&request_locale=en|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref> * TS2250 - Half-height, single slot LTO-5 tape drive.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM System Storage TS2250 Tape Drive Express Model H5S incorporates IBM LTO Ultrium 5 tape drive technology|url=http://www-01.ibm.com/common/ssi/ShowDoc.wss?docURL=/common/ssi/rep_ca/9/897/ENUS110-069/index.html&lang=en&request_locale=en|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref> * TS2350 – Full height, single slot LTO-5 tape drive (equivalent to the previous LTO 3580 tape drive).<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM System Storage TS2350 Tape Drive Express Model S53 incorporates IBM LTO Ultrium 5 tape drive technology|url=http://www-01.ibm.com/common/ssi/ShowDoc.wss?docURL=/common/ssi/rep_ca/6/897/ENUS110-106/index.html&lang=en&request_locale=en|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref>
====Virtual tape libraries==== * TS7700 series - The TS7700 is a virtualization engine (virtual tape library) for System z (mainframe) that uses disk drives for cache to accelerate backup operations. The design is intended to protect data while having shorter backup windows. End-to-end encryption protects data in motion, on cache hard drives and on tape. TS7740 is designed to speed up tape backups and restores by using a tiered hierarchy of disk and tape to make more efficient use of tape drives. TS7720 provides a hard-drive based "deep cache" solution for frequently accessed data.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM Virtualization Engine TS7700 supports disk-based encryption|url=http://www-01.ibm.com/common/ssi/ShowDoc.wss?docURL=/common/ssi/rep_ca/0/897/ENUS112-160/index.html&lang=en&request_locale=en|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref>
* IBM System Storage TS7680 ProtecTIER Deduplication Gateway for System z - Combines a virtual tape library solution, with IBM HyperFactor deduplication technology and integrated native replication technology to optimize disk-based storage for System z applications that traditionally use tape.<ref>{{cite web|title=3958-DE2 (TS7680) product introduction|url=http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/ts7680/cust/topic/com.ibm.storage.3958.doc/3958_DE2_c_product_introduction.html|work=3958-DE2 (TS7680) Customer Information Center|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref>
* IBM System Storage TS7650G ProtecTIER Deduplication Gateway - Designed to meet the disk-based data protection needs of the enterprise data center while reducing costs. The solution offers inline deduplication performance and scalability up to 1 petabyte (PB) of physical storage capacity per system that can provide up to 25 PB or more backup storage capacity.<ref>{{cite web|title=Introduction to the TS7650G (Gateway)|url=http://pic.dhe.ibm.com/infocenter/ts7650/cust/topic/com.ibm.storage.ts7650_3-1.cust.doc/ts7650gipg_introduction.html|work=TS7650 V3.1 Customer Information Center|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref>
===For midrange and entry workloads===
====Tape libraries==== * TS3310 - Expandable library with up to 18 LTO-3, LTO-4 or LTO-5 drives (409 cartridges maximum with expansion modules.) * TS3200 - Up to four LTO-3, LTO-4, LTO-5, or LTO-6 drive library using half-height drive assemblies (48 cartridges).<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|title=IBM System Storage TS3100 and TS3200 Tape Libraries - IBM Redbooks Product Guide|url=http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/abstracts/tips0832.html?Open|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref> * TS3100 - Up to two LTO-3, LTO-4, LTO-5, or LTO-6 drive library using half-height drive assemblies (24 cartridges).<ref name="autogenerated2"/>
====Tape drives==== * The IBM System Storage TS2900 Tape Autoloader - Designed for entry-level automation for backup and archiving in small-to-medium business environments. The TS2900 is available with IBM Linear Tape-Open (LTO) 5 Half-High and LTO-4 Half-High SAS tape technology.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM System Storage TS2900 Tape Autoloader - IBM Redbooks Product Guide|url=http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/Redbooks.nsf/RedbookAbstracts/tips0833.html|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref> * TS2350 - External standalone or rack mountable shelf unit with a native physical capacity of 1.5 TB. The IBM Ultrium 5 technology is designed to allow media partitioning, IBM Linear Tape File System (LTFS) technology and encryption of data and WORM cartridges.<ref>{{cite web|title=Overview of the IBM System Storage TS2350 Tape Drive Express|url=http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/redbooks/SG245946/wwhelp/wwhimpl/api.htm?href=7-1.htm|work=IBM System Storage Tape Library Guide for Open Systems|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref> * TS2250 - External standalone or rack mountable shelf unit with a native physical capacity of 1.5 TB.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM System Storage TS2250 Tape Drive Express Model H5S incorporates IBM LTO Ultrium 5 tape drive technology|url=http://www-01.ibm.com/common/ssi/ShowDoc.wss?docURL=/common/ssi/rep_ca/4/877/ENUSZG10-0094/index.html&lang=en_US|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref>
====Virtual tape libraries==== * ProtecTIER TS7650 Virtual tape library for Open Systems - Preconfigured virtual tape library with a capacity of up to 900 TB. It consists of IBM storage, IBM systems, and the IBM ProtecTIER data deduplication software designed to improve backup and recovery operations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Available models|url=http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/redbooks/SG247968/wwhelp/wwhimpl/api.htm?href=2-4-3.htm|work=IBM System Storage TS7600 with ProtecTIER Version 3.1|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref> * TS7620 ProtecTIER Deduplication Appliance - Preconfigured repository that can be configured with either a Virtual Tape Library or Symantec OpenStorage interface with a capacity of up to 35 TB.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM System Storage TS7620 Expansion Drawer provides additional repository capacities for TS7620 systems|url=http://www-01.ibm.com/common/ssi/cgi-bin/ssialias?infotype=AN&subtype=CA&htmlfid=897/ENUS113-003&appname=USN|publisher=IBM|accessdate=11 February 2013}}</ref> ==Flash Storage== IBM offers a range of dedicated flash storage systems and flash storage capabilities in a number of other systems and solutions. In April 2013, the company announced a plan for a $1 billion investment in flash storage research and development to continue to enhance these capabilities.<ref>{{cite web|last=Henschen|first=Doug|title=IBM: Flash Storage Hits Tipping Point|url=http://www.informationweek.com/storage/systems/ibm-flash-storage-hits-tipping-point/240152747|work=InformationWeek|accessdate=2 May 2013}}</ref> IBM acquired flash storage system maker Texas Memory Systems in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM Plans to Acquire Texas Memory Systems|url=http://www-03.ibm.com/press/us/en/pressrelease/38594.wss|publisher=IBM|accessdate=2 May 2013}}</ref> The IBM FlashSystem products announced in April 2013 are based on technology from this acquisition.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kraft|first=Darryl|title=IBM FlashSystem Storage Appliances Launch With $1 Billion Investment|url=http://www.eweek.com/storage/ibm-flashsystem-storage-appliances-launch-with-1-billion-investment|work=eWeek|accessdate=2 May 2013}}</ref>
===IBM FlashSystem 820=== [http://www.ibm.com/systems/storage/flash/720-820/ FlashSystem 820] is composed of enterprise [[multi-level cell]] (eMLC) flash technology. The system is a 1U rackmount unit with up to 24TB of usable storage capacity. The system supports a high-availability architecture with ECC, IBM Variable Stripe RAID, and two-dimensional flash RAID for data protection and offers hot-swap flash modules and power supplies. With read IOPS of 525,000 and write IOPS of 280,000, FlashSystem 820 is targeted to read-heavy workloads, where workloads are distributed across multiple servers.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM FlashSystem 720 and IBM FlashSystem 820|url=http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/abstracts/tips1003.html|publisher=IBM|accessdate=2 May 2013}}</ref>
===IBM FlashSystem 810=== The [http://www.ibm.com/systems/storage/flash/710-810/ FlashSystem 810] is composed of enterprise multi-level cell (eMLC) flash technology and can scale up to 10 TB usable storage capacity available in 2 TB increments. The system supports ECC, IBM Variable Stripe RAID and Active Spare features for data protection and offers hot-swap power supplies. FlashSystem 810 is targeted to read-heavy workloads, where workload is distributed across multiple servers.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM FlashSystem 710 and IBM FlashSystem 810|url=http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/abstracts/tips1002.html|publisher=IBM|accessdate=2 May 2013}}</ref>
===IBM FlashSystem 720=== [http://www-03.ibm.com/systems/storage/flash/720-820/index.html FlashSystem 720] is a 1U rackmount system, offering 12 TB of usable capacity based on [[single-level cell]] (SLC) flash technology. FlashSystem 720 supports a high-availability architecture with ECC, IBM Variable Stripe RAIDTM, and two-dimensional flash RAID to protect data in case of a flash chip or module failure. The system offers hot-swap flash modules and power supplies. FlashSystem 720 is targeted to write-heavy enterprise workloads, with 525,000 read IOPS and 400,000 write IOPS.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM FlashSystem 720 and IBM FlashSystem 820|url=http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/abstracts/tips1003.html|publisher=IBM|accessdate=2 May 2013}}</ref>
===IBM FlashSystem 710=== FlashSystem 710 is a 1U rackmount system composed of single-level cell (SLC) flash technology, supporting up to 5 TB usable capacity in 1 TB increments. The system supports ECC, IBM Variable Stripe RAIDTM and Active Spare features for data protection and offers hot-swap power supplies. FlashSystem 710 is targeted to write-heavy enterprise workloads.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM FlashSystem 710 and IBM FlashSystem 810|url=http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/abstracts/tips1002.html|publisher=IBM|accessdate=2 May 2013}}</ref>
===Other flash storage capabilities===
[http://www.ibm.com/systems/power/hardware/peripherals/ssd/details.html IBM EXP 30 Ultra SSD I/O Drawer] – 1U rackmount drawer for IBM Power System offerings. Supports up to 11.6 TB of storage and up to 480,000 IOPS
High IOPS PCIe Adapters – PCIe card adapters for IBM System x servers, offering capacities up to 2.4TB
[http://www.ibm.com/systems/x/options/storage/solidstate/ eXFlash for System x] – An internal expansion unit for IBM System x and IBM BladeCenter systems. Supports up to 1.8 TB of storage per “pack.”
==Other storage products and capabilities==
===SAN Volume Controller=== The [[IBM SAN Volume Controller]] (SVC) is a block storage virtualization appliance. Because the IBM Storwize V7000 uses SVC code, it can also be used to perform storage virtualization in exactly the same way as the SVC. Since mid-2012 it offers real time compression with no performance impact, saving up to 80% of disk utilization. SVC can be configured on a Stretched Cluster Mode, with automatic failover between two datacenters and can have SSD (Solid State Drives) than perform sub-LUN automatic tiering (EasyTier).
===SmartCloud Storage Access=== IBM SmartCloud Storage Access is a software solution designed to create a private cloud storage service on existing storage devices. The software can be configured to allow users self-service, Internet-based access for account creation, storage provisioning and file management. The software offers simple management with monitoring and reporting capabilities, including storage usage by user and group definitions.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mearian|first=Lucas|title=IBM gives cloud storage controls to corporate users|url=http://www.itworld.com/storage/341056/ibm-gives-cloud-storage-controls-corporate-users|work=IT World|accessdate=11 February 2013}}</ref>
===Real-time Compression Appliances=== The IBM Real-time Compression Appliances are designed to compress active primary NAS storage by up to 80 percent with no performance degradation and with no IT or application changes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Overview of the compression appliances|url=http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/rtca/rtcaic/topic/com.ibm.storage.rtca.help.doc/in_c_product_over.html|work=IBM Real-time Compression Appliances (RTCAs) Information Center|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref> * STN7800 – The STN7800 is a 2U rack-mounted appliance, equipped with 1-gigabit copper Ethernet ports, 10-gigabit optical Ethernet (10GBASE-SR)ports, or both configured as: ** Four 10-GbE optical ports and eight 1-GbE copper ports ** Eight 10-GbE optical ports ** Sixteen 1-GbE copper ports<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM Real-time Compression Appliance STN7800 supports IBM Compression Software|url=http://www-01.ibm.com/common/ssi/cgi-bin/ssialias?infotype=an&subtype=ca&appname=gpateam&supplier=897&letternum=ENUS113-012|publisher=IBM|accessdate=11 February 2013}}</ref>
* STN6500 - The STN6500 is a 2U rack-mounted appliance, equipped with 16 one-gigabit copper Ethernet ports and 1 management port. IBM announced that the STN6500 will be withdrawn in March 2013.<ref name="www-01.ibm.com">{{cite web|title=Hardware withdrawal: IBM Real-time Compression Appliance STN6500 and STN6800 - Replacements available|url=http://www-01.ibm.com/common/ssi/cgi-bin/ssialias?infotype=AN&subtype=CA&htmlfid=897/ENUS913-009&appname=USN|publisher=IBM|accessdate=11 February 2013}}</ref> * STN6800 - The STN6800 is a 2U rack-mounted appliance, equipped with 1-gigabit copper Ethernet ports, 10-gigabit optical Ethernet (10GBASE-SR) ports, or both configured as: ** Four 10-GbE optical ports and eight 1-GbE copper ports ** Eight 10-GbE optical ports :IBM announced that the STN6800 will be withdrawn in March 2013.<ref name="www-01.ibm.com"/>
===Linear Tape File System (LTFS)=== [[LTFS]] works in conjunction with LTO tape technology to simplify accessing data stored on an IBM tape cartridge. LTFS allows users to run any application designed for disk files against tape data without concern for the fact that the data is physically stored on tape.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM Linear Tape File System|url=http://www-03.ibm.com/systems/storage/tape/ltfs/index.html|publisher=IBM|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref>
===Active Cloud Engine=== The Active Cloud Engine (ACE) is an advanced form of multiple site replication. ACE is designed to allow different types of cloud implementations to exchange data dynamically. ACE does is designed to extend the SONAS capability for a single, centrally managed namespace, to a truly distributed, geographically-dispersed, global namespace.<ref>{{cite web|title=SONAS Active Cloud Engine: Overview|url=http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/redbooks/SG247962/wwhelp/wwhimpl/api.htm?href=4-1.htm|work=SONAS Implementation and Best Practices Guide|publisher=IBM|accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref>
===IBM Easy Tier=== IBM Easy Tier is designed to automate data placement throughout the disk pool on certain IBM storage systems to improve the efficiency and performance of the storage system. Easy Tier is designed to relocate data (at the extent level) across up to three drive tiers automatically and without disruption to application. Easy Tier also rebalances [[Extent (file systems)|extents]] within the same disk tier - even within homogeneous and single-tier extent pools.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM System Storage DS8000 Easy Tier|url=http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/abstracts/redp4667.html|publisher=IBM|accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref> IBM Easy Tier is available on the DS8000 Series, Storwize V7000 Unified and SAN Volume Controller.
